The incorporation of challenge enhances the learning of chronology from a virtual display
Download PDF
Download PDF
  • Original Article
  • Published: 23 May 2007

The incorporation of challenge enhances the learning of chronology from a virtual display

  • Nigel Foreman1,
  • Liliya Korallo1,
  • David Newson1 &
  • Natalie Sarantos1 

Virtual Reality volume 12, pages107–113(2008)Cite this article

  • 105 Accesses

  • 2 Citations

  • Metrics details

Abstract

In earlier studies investigating the learning of historical chronology, virtual fly-throughs were used in which successive historical events were represented by images on virtual screens, placed in temporal-spatial sequence. Undergraduate students benefited more than school-age children from virtual 3D (compared to 2D) training, perhaps because they took on the task as a challenge. In this study a modification of the earlier paradigm was used, in a game-like format, in which successive screens (paintings, representing epochs of art history) had to be memorised and anticipated during training, the participant’s score accumulating on the screen. Compared with PowerPoint and verbal-semantic training conditions, VE training resulted in more rapid learning, better recall of associated semantic information and error-free recall of the picture sequence. Possible applications of this paradigm for teaching were discussed.

Introduction

Conveying notions of historical chronology has always posed difficulties for teachers. The learning of history involves the retention of dates and events and their correct sequential ordering, usually following the study of books and worksheets containing names, events and dates. Many students seem to have difficulty recalling such information, perhaps because of the limitations of verbal-semantic memory stores and the abstract nature of time—the absence of cues that place events in any intuitive chronological order—and various solutions have been proposed (Cooper 1994, 2000; Friedman 1982; Hodkinson 1995; Hoodless 1996; O’Hara and O’Hara 2001; Partington 1980; Wood and Holden 1995; Yaxley 2004).

In an effort to improve the teaching and learning of history using multimedia technology, Masterman and Rogers (2002) used an interactive package, for which a 2D timeline was depicted like a winding road on a computer screen. Pupils could mouse-click pictures spaced out in temporal-spatial order along the timeline to access information about particular historical events or figures, after which they could return to survey the timeline display and select an image at another point in history. Although much appreciated by staff and pupils, the technique was not assessed as such. To be beneficial as a teaching aid, the technique needs to increase information retention (in correct sequence) compared with traditional classroom methods such as “washing-line” timelines, or the presentation of information as written text.

A technology that could be especially useful in this context is virtual environment (VE) technology, since 3D environments can allow a user to fly past historical sequential events as though using a time machine (Pedley et al. 2003). Kullberg (1995) created a large branching display representing the history of photography. A participant could follow a particular line of development, mouse-clicking on particular photographs to obtain information about the date and photographer. Once again, no attempt was made to formally assess the benefits of using the software by comparison with alternatives such as the reading of books on the history of photography or seeing pictures displayed individually on a computer screen with the accompanying information.

There are reasons for thinking that experiencing the passage of time by flying through a VE may fix events more clearly in memory than the use of semantic information or successive screen images. In particular, a participant flying through a VE has autonomous and active control of their movements (Wilson 1997), and they may treat the material to be learned as a series of “places”, rather like the memorising of a row of familiar shops. This kind of spatial information can be acquired successfully from a VE, as demonstrated by a number of studies in which participants successfully familiarised themselves with buildings or towns (Bliss et al. 1997; Foreman et al. 2003; Foreman et al. 2005; O’Neil 1992; Ruddle et al. 1997; Wilson 1997; Rose and Foreman 1999).

In previous studies using fly-throughs, Foreman et al. (2007) found that success in using VEs to learn sequential historical information varied according to participant age. Undergraduate students learned the history of an imaginary planet moderately better following VE training than after washing-line based training or reading text. However, middle school children learned no more about feudal England from a VE than from a series of pictures printed on paper or displayed individually on a computer screen. Indeed, primary school-aged children learned less about eras of history from a VE than from other media, perhaps because they were overwhelmed by the novelty of using the VE medium. Undergraduate participants appeared to treat the experience rather like a computer game and challenged themselves to complete the task successfully.

If VE training improves on other methods because it engages spatial (rather than semantic) memory, it is perhaps not surprising that challenge is beneficial. In an early account of cognitive spatial mapping as a means of remembering places, Tolman (1948) emphasised that places in space are likely to be recalled according to what happened there (for example, where a reward was obtained).

In order to investigate whether cognitive challenge is an important factor that promotes chronological learning from a VE, the present study used a modification of the earlier design to teach participants about art history in the form of a computer game. Nine pictures by different artists were selected, clearly spaced in time and representing different eras of painting. For one participant group, these were presented as a fly-through which could be navigated, for another as a PowerPoint series of full screen images, or, for a third group, as text alone. Screens were initially blank, each picture being revealed only after the participant had made an anticipatory guess as to its identity. In the VE, a score (number of correct responses) was depicted on the screen. We hypothesised that in the training phase, the VE condition would give rise to the most rapid learning (requiring the smallest number of fly-through passes to achieve a performance criterion) than either of the other two methods, also that in post-criterion testing, recall of the picture sequence and picture-related semantic information would be more accurate following training in the VE condition.

Method

Participants

Participants were 36 students (18 male, 18 female) drawn from an undergraduate student population. They were aged 18–27 years, and all had normal or corrected to normal vision.

Equipment

Images were displayed on a 30 × 25 cm monitor, running on a Pentium 3 computer with 128 Mb RAM and equipped with a NVidia Riva TNT2 graphics card. Virtools 3D construction software was used to create the virtual fly-through. The nine pictures were digitised and pasted on to successive screens (placed alternately to the left and right of the forward movement trajectory) in the virtual display, with the title of the picture, the name of the artist and the date of the painting displayed in the lower part of each picture. Virtual movement speed was set at 30 (virtual) units/s and the total distance from the start to the finish of the series of images, 1680 units. Internet explorer was used for the browser version of the software, giving a fly-through duration of 56 s. from the first picture to the last. (The user would therefore take about 7 s to “walk” from one picture to the next when continuously depressing the forward keyboard key). For the PowerPoint condition, a standard presentation was created, every picture image being preceded by a blank slide. For the verbal control condition, the information about each picture was provided as text on plain paper.

The pictures were selected to be well spaced in historical time and were:

  • Mona Lisa (Leonardo da Vinci), 1503

  • Market woman with vegetable stall (Pieter Aertsen), 1567

  • Venus playing the harp (Giovanni Lanfranco), 1630

  • A young girl reading (Jean-Honore Fragonard), 1776

  • Sunflowers (Vincent van Gogh), 1888

  • The old guitarist (Pablo Picasso), 1903

  • Twilight (Vassily Kandinsky), 1943

  • Movement in squares (Bridget Riley), 1961

  • A bigger Grand Canyon (David Hockney), 1998

Procedure

Participants were trained individually. Those in the computer conditions were seated at a comfortable distance (approximately 40 cm) from the computer monitor. For VE participants this displayed the virtual environment (Fig. 1) which they were instructed to observe carefully while depressing a “forward” keyboard key to move through and past the series of nine pictures. Only forward movement was allowed, along a straight, predetermined trajectory. Participants could pause at any point. They were told to look carefully at each successive picture and try to remember the order of pictures using terms such as “blue flowers” as descriptors. No attempt was made to specifically draw their attention to the semantic information on the pictures. For the first fly-through, the participant was shown each of the pictures in turn. At the end of the sequence of nine images, a message was displayed indicating that the sequence would now begin again and the viewpoint returned to a point approaching the first picture. On the second fly-through, at each picture, when the picture screen was in prominent view, the viewpoint was held stationary. The participant had to describe the picture on that screen, and if correct, the experimenter could click on the screen to display the picture, after which the participant was free to move on toward the next screen. If the participant was incorrect, they were asked to choose again and an error was recorded. When a picture was correctly anticipated at the first guess, a counter displayed on the top right of the screen, which began at zero at the start of the fly-through sequence, was advanced by 1. (At the beginning of each fly-through the counter was reset to zero). The Experimenter noted errors, and continued testing until the participant had achieved two successive error-free fly-throughs. In the PowerPoint condition, the training process occurred as above, but the participant saw the sequence of nine pictures displayed as successive full-screen images, thus without any virtual spatial context. At the first pass, participants were shown each picture in turn. At the second and subsequent passes, a blank screen was displayed and was replaced with the image only when correctly anticipated by the participant, reproducing the procedure in the VE condition. An interval of 5 s elapsed between a correct response and the display of the subsequent screen, approximating the time for which the VE images were visible to participants on the screen post-choice. In the verbal-semantic condition, participants were tested as above but with semantic information only (the picture name and date, and the artist’s name as text on a printed page), no images being displayed. The number of passes through the materials (information provided about each of the nine successive paintings) to achieve criterion, and errors to criterion were recorded as for the other conditions.

Following training, after an interval of approximately 5 min, each participant was assessed using three tests. For the first, they were given a pen and paper with numbers 1–9 listed vertically down the page, and asked to fill in as much information as they could recall about the nine successive pictures, if possible providing the painter’s name and the picture’s title and date. This sheet was then removed, and they were given a second sheet with a list of nine questions about picture order, of the form “Did Kandinsky come before Matisse?” Following this, they were given a single sheet of paper on which all nine pictures were shown, in random order, but without any verbal information displayed. Each picture was given a letter (A–I) and they were asked to place the pictures in the correct order, reflecting their order in the training phase, by writing down the correct sequence of letters. Unlimited time was allowed for these three tests, although they were typically completed in about 8 min. The participant was then debriefed about the nature of the experiment.

The dependent measures recorded were: for training, the number of trials (fly-throughs, passes) required, excluding the first, in which the pictures/information were displayed to them, to achieve a criterion of two successive error-free passes. Also recorded was the total number of errors made before criterion was reached. Dependent measures from the testing phase were: (1) the amount of information provided correctly in the first test (nine pictures × three items of information [painter, picture title, date], so a possible 27), (2) the number of questions answered correctly (out of a total of nine) and (3) the number of pictures placed in the correct order, calculated using an REM (removed) score (Foreman et al. 2007), which reflected, for each picture placed, the difference in list position between its correct position and the position in which it was placed by the participant. For example, a picture that actually occurred in list position 6 but was placed by the participant in list position 4 received a score of 2. This score provides a measure of the organisation of picture ordering (Foreman et al. 2007). The total of all REM scores for all nine pictures was totalled and this became the participant’s overall REM score for the purposes of statistical analysis. Correct responses were totalled within successive serial order blocks (1–3, 4–6, 7–9) to identify where (in the serial order positions) errors were most frequent (cf. Atkinson and Shiffrin 1971; Broadbent 1981; Barraclough and Foreman 1994).

Note that both of the computer-based groups had seen the pictures while the verbal controls had not. Clearly, verbal information could also have been provided by computer though we used the paper-based control condition as a reflection of what usually happens in class rooms; students are usually expected to learn information from written text, so that the verbal condition here was the most valid as a procedure against which to compare the computer conditions. In post-criterion testing, although the verbal control participants had not seen the pictures, their picture ordering was regarded as a strong control insofar as some participants in the computer-based conditions might have been able to order at least some pictures from their general knowledge of art, and some may have identified (and/or roughly dated) some of the paintings used. The degree to which verbal controls could order picture images without having viewed them in training provided the most valid “chance” baseline against which to compare the computer-based conditions. Note also that the verbal control condition was a strong control insofar as participants were remembering successive items with specific attention having been drawn to their verbal descriptions (titles, artist names and dates), by virtue of the nature of the verbal-semantic display.

Results

Trials and errors to criterion in the training phase

Trials to criterion (i.e. the number of passes through the materials, excluding the first, required to reach criterion) was analysed using the Kruskal–Wallis non-parametric analysis of variance. Groups differed significantly, χ 2(2) = 26.85; p < 0.001, the Mann–Whitney U-test (corrected for ties) revealing that the VE group took significantly fewer trial/passes than either the PowerPoint or the verbal control groups, U(N 1 =  N 2 = 12) = 25.5; p = 0.006 and U = 0; p < 0.001, respectively, while the PowerPoint group required fewer trials/passes than the verbal controls, U = 1; p < 0.001. The results are illustrated in Fig. 2. For total errors to criterion (i.e. incorrect anticipations of an upcoming picture), data were well distributed and were analysed parametrically. A one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) for independent groups followed by post hoc comparisons (least significant difference test), revealed that groups again differed, F(2,33) = 67.67; p < 0.001. The VE and PowerPoint groups almost differed, p = 0.067, but the VE group differed significantly from the verbal controls, p < 0.001, and the PowerPoint and verbal controls differed significantly, p < 0.001. The results are illustrated in Fig. 3.

Analysis of error positions was conducted by totalling the number of errors made by each participant in training within three successive list position blocks, representing positions 1–3, 4–6 and 7–9, respectively. These are shown in Fig. 4. Errors were so rare in the VE condition that the median scores for all blocks were zero, while the PowerPoint group made errors most frequently in the middle list positions, and controls made many errors, the largest number again occurring in middle list positions.

Post-criterion testing

When assessed for their ability to remember information about the pictures, groups differed significantly, F(2,30) = 8.22; p < 0.001, the VE group differing significantly from both the PowerPoint and verbal controls (p < 0.001) though the latter two groups failed to differ (p > 0.05) (Fig. 5). Non-parametric analyses were used for other post-criterion measures. When answering questions of the form “Did X come before Y?”, group differences were so close to statistical significance, χ 2(2) = 5.17; p = 0.076, that post-hoc comparisons were made, the Mann–Whitney U-test suggesting a superiority of the VE group compared with PowerPoint and verbal control groups combined, U(N 1 = 12, N 2 = 24) = 85; p = 0.04, and superiority of the VE group over the PowerPoint group, U = 35.5; p = 0.028.

Assessed for their ability to place paintings in their correct historical order, using the “removed” score analysis (see above), performance in the VE group was entirely error-free. Two participants in the PowerPoint group made 2 errors each, while 11 out of the 12 controls made between 2 and 4 errors (overall group mean: 2.5 errors).

Gender differences were examined for all variables but none was statistically significant.

Discussion

The results of previous studies using virtual environments to convey the notion of “time passing” have produced mixed results, insofar as younger age groups appeared overawed by the medium but older participants appeared to treat the experience as a computer game, and retained more information following VE training than after 2D “washing line” training or with verbal information presented on paper (Foreman et al. 2007). In the current study, an element of challenge was specifically introduced, participants having to indicate the identity of each up-coming picture as it was approached. Moreover, as they guessed correctly, a score was displayed on the screen, so that they were additionally motivated to guess accurately and improve their performance across trials. The format used here more closely approximated that with which students would be familiar from their use of computer games.

The results of the current study reflect a very large and statistically reliable benefit of using such a procedure in a VE, compared with a PowerPoint condition; thus the simple use of a computer display (which is itself motivating; cf. Smart 1996; Underwood and Underwood 1990; Watson 1993) is not responsible for the advantage per se. However, it is noticeable that in many respects (such as trials and errors to criterion) both computer-based conditions improved, to some extent, upon the presentation of text based material in conventional paper-based worksheet form. The results reinforce Haydn’s (1999) scepticism about the benefits of using technology such as PowerPoint in classroom history teaching, but indicate that alternative media can be adapted to enhance learning. Clearly, the purpose of using alternative technologies to convey the idea of chronological sequence is to enhance long-term retention, and further studies would be welcome that test retention over longer post-training intervals, and use examination performance as further indicators of efficacy.

In our earlier study (Foreman et al. 2007), in which undergraduate students benefited most from VE training, the use of a VE seemed to enhance memory particularly for materials in middle list positions (positions from which information is most often forgotten in studies of conventional list learning; see Atkinson and Shiffrin 1971; Broadbent 1981; Barraclough and Foreman 1994). However, in the present study the degree of benefit was substantially greater than in the earlier one since the participants using the VE display produced error-free recall of positional information (across all list positions), while both PowerPoint and verbal control participants exhibited the usual serial order effect. It remains to be seen whether the introduction of cognitive challenge would enhance learning in younger age groups, or other groups who appear to have difficulty grasping the concept of time from conventional materials, such as disabled pupils (Turner 1998).

A surprising feature of the present data was that in terms of information recall, participants in the verbal control group performed especially poorly, and PowerPoint participants also gave poorer performance than the VEs. We cannot say why this occurred, particularly since the former two groups had been given more trials than VEs, so had more opportunity to learn the verbal information. However, just as their learning was slow compared with the VEs, their retention was also poor. It seems that verbal control participants may have focused on particular items (e.g. the picture name) while the experience of seeing each picture with its accompanying textual information appears to have enabled VE participants to absorb more of all types of information (both spatial-sequential and associated verbal) simultaneously, and to do so quickly. However, performance on information recalled, even in the VE group was far from perfect, since they remembered only half of the 27 items of information provided (see Fig. 5). Further studies of strategy use are needed to resolve these issues.

That the VE group showed perfect recall across all list positions perhaps reflects the fact that they were treating the nine items as a series of places within virtual space (rather like remembering the order of a line of familiar shops) rather than as a simple list of word items. (Simple word lists have, hitherto, been the standard materials for testing primacy-recency effects in memory; see Broadbent 1981; Barraclough and Foreman 1994). However, the clear serial order effects seen in the PowerPoint, and especially in the verbal, group suggests that these groups were treating the items to be recalled as a participant might treat a list of simple words. This illustrates a potential benefit in using a VE, since it encourages the use of spatial memory. Spatial memory is arguably a high capacity store, apparently free of the conventional constraints (such as storage buffer size). The design of virtual environments for teaching purposes should take into account the fact that virtual spatial experience makes available forms of temporal-spatial memory storage that are difficult to access via alternative means such as written text, or successive images that are detached from each other in time-space. As such, the use of VEs might be beneficial in future not only in the teaching of a range of subjects having a chronological component, including history, but also the history of medicine, science and religion, and geology, archaeology, and political and economic science.
